conclusion: The problem involves finding the charge Q on the capacitor after the circuit stabilizes, given the circuit components and their values.
The circuit contains a power supply (E = 6V, r = 2Ω), a capacitor (C = 10μF), three resistors (R₁ = 2Ω, R₂ = 3Ω, R₃ = 6Ω), and a switch S.
When the circuit stabilizes, the capacitor will be fully charged and act as an open circuit for DC analysis, meaning no current flows through it.
After the capacitor is fully charged, the path through the capacitor becomes an open circuit, and the voltage across the capacitor equals the voltage across R₁.
R₂ and R₃ are in series, so their equivalent resistance is R₂₃ = R₂ + R₃ = 3Ω + 6Ω = 9Ω.
R₁ and R₂₃ are in parallel, so their equivalent resistance is R_parallel = (R₁ × R₂₃)/(R₁ + R₂₃) = (2Ω × 9Ω)/(2Ω + 9Ω) = 18Ω/11Ω = 1.636Ω.
The total circuit resistance is R_total = r + R_parallel = 2Ω + 1.636Ω = 3.636Ω.
Using Ohm's law, the main circuit current is I = E/R_total = 6V/3.636Ω = 1.65A.
The voltage across the parallel combination is V_parallel = I × R_parallel = 1.65A × 1.636Ω = 2.699V.
Using voltage division, the current through R₁ is I₁ = V_parallel/R₁ = 2.699V/2Ω = 1.35A.
The voltage across R₁ (which equals the voltage across the capacitor) is V₁ = I₁ × R₁ = 1.35A × 2Ω = 2.7V.
Using the capacitance formula, the charge on the capacitor is Q = C × V = 10μF × 2.7V = 27μC.
An alternative calculation method involves using the voltage divider principle to directly calculate the voltage across R₁.
Using the voltage divider principle, the voltage across R₁ (and the capacitor) is V₁ = E × [R₁/(R₁ + r + (R₂ + R₃)×R₁/(R₁ + R₂ + R₃))] = 2.7V.
Using the capacitance formula again, the charge on the capacitor is Q = C × V₁ = 10μF × 2.7V = 27μC.
